resources.string: Allows Et2Brutus to interact with UI elements on screen for automated input.

"Welcome to Screen Bruteforcer! Here's how to get started:

" "1. Grant Permissions:
" " - The app needs two permissions to work. Please grant both 'Draw Over Other Apps' and 'Accessibility Service' on the main screen.

" "2. The Floating Button:
" " - Press (Ctrl + G) on a physical keyboard to show or hide the main floating button.
" " - You can drag this button anywhere on the screen. The app will remember its position.

" "3. Using the Menu:
" " - Tap the floating button to open the menu.
" " - 'Start': Begins the bruteforce process.
" " - 'Pause': Pauses the current process.
" " - 'Stop': Stops the process and resets.
" " - 'Dictionary': Select a dictionary file for the bruteforce.
" " - 'Settings': Configure advanced options like password length and character set.

" "4. Identifying UI Elements:
" " - To tell the app where to type and what to click, you need to position the smaller config buttons.
" " - 'Input': Drag this button over the text field where the app should type (e.g., a password field).
" " - 'Submit': Drag this over the button that submits the form (e.g., a 'Login' or 'Go' button).
" " - 'Popup': If a popup appears after a failed attempt (e.g., 'Incorrect password'), drag this over the button that closes the popup (e.g., an 'OK' button).
" " - When a button has successfully identified a UI element, it will change color."

"Welcome to Screen Bruteforcer! Here's how to get started:

" "1. Grant Permissions:
" " - The app needs two permissions to work. Please grant both 'Draw Over Other Apps' and 'Accessibility Service' on the main screen.

" "2. The Floating Button:
" " - Press (Ctrl + G) on a physical keyboard to show or hide the main floating button.
" " - You can drag this button anywhere on the screen. The app will remember its position.

" "3. Using the Menu:
" " - Tap the floating button to open the menu.
" " - 'Start': Begins the bruteforce process.
" " - 'Pause': Pauses the current process.
" " - 'Stop': Stops the process and resets.
" " - 'Dictionary': Select a dictionary file for the bruteforce.
" " - 'Settings': Configure advanced options like password length and character set.

" "4. Identifying UI Elements:
" " - To tell the app where to type and what to click, you need to position the smaller config buttons.
" " - 'Input': Drag this button over the text field where the app should type (e.g., a password field).
" " - 'Submit': Drag this over the button that submits the form (e.g., a 'Login' or 'Go' button).
" " - 'Popup': If a popup appears after a failed attempt (e.g., 'Incorrect password'), drag this over the button that closes the popup (e.g., an 'OK' button).
" " - When a button has successfully identified a UI element, it will change color."
Overlay permission is required for the floating controls.
Overlay permission is implicitly granted on this Android version.
Please enable the \'%s\' in Accessibility settings.
Enable permissions, then start the service. A floating button will appear.
This app helps you automate repetitive tasks by simulating screen taps.
First, please grant both \'Draw Over Other Apps\' and \'Accessibility Service\' permissions on the main screen.
Press (Ctrl + G) on a physical keyboard to show or hide the floating menu at any time.
Tap the floating dagger icon to open the menu. You can drag the icon anywhere on the screen.
Drag the \'Input\' button over the text field where the app should type (e.g., a password field).
Drag the \'Submit\' button over the button that submits the form (e.g., a \'Login\' button).
If a popup appears after a failed attempt, drag the \'Popup\' button over the button that closes it (e.g., \'OK\').
Once the \'Input\' and \'Submit\' buttons have identified their targets, you can start the process from the menu.
Are you sure you want to delete profile \'%1$s\'?
Save your current setup to get started.
